rev.comment: /* Media censorship and circumvention */ I will add a better picture a minute, chill
rev.diff:
Line 436: Line 436:
Starting just after midnight local time on the night of 27/28 January<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> the Egyptian government almost entirely cut off [[Internet in Egypt#2011 Internet shutdown|
Starting just after midnight local time on the night of 27/28 January<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> the Egyptian government almost entirely cut off [[Internet in Egypt#2011 Internet shutdown|
Internet access]]<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock">{{cite web| last =Cowie| first =James| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Egypt Leaves the Internet| work =| publisher =[[Renesys]]| date =| url =http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml | doi =| accessdate =28 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w51j0pga |archivedate=28 January 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock">{{cite news | first=Jeremy | last=Kirk | pages= | language =| title=With Wired Internet Locked, Egypt Looks to the Sky | date=28 January 2011 | work=[[IDG News]]/[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] | url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/218064/with_wired_internet_locked_egypt_looks_to_the_sky.html |accessdate=28 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w518Yu9B |archivedate=28 January 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pomed.org/blog/2011/01/egypt-ap-confirms-government-has-disrupted-internet-service.html/ |title=Egypt: AP Confirms Government has Disrupted Internet Service |publisher=pomed.org |date= |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> in an act of unprecedented<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock" /> [[Internet censorship]]. About 3,500 [[Border Gateway Protocol]] (BGP) routes to Egyptian networks were shut down from about 12:10 am to 12:35 am 28 January.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> The shutdown happened within the space of a few tens of minutes, not instantaneously. According to Renesys, [[Telecom Egypt]] started shutting down at 12:12am, [[Vodafone|Raya/Vodafone]] at 12:13am, [[Link Egypt]] at 12:17am, [[Etisalat Misr]] at 12:19am, and [[Internet Egypt]] at 12:25am.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Renesys interpreted the shutdown as people getting phone calls one at a time, telling them to take themselves off the air, rather than an automated system taking all providers down at once.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Facebook confirmed a decrease in traffic from Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-54463420110127|title=Facebook Says Has Seen Drop in Traffic from Egypt|work=[[Reuters]]|author=Oreskovic, Alexei; Chiacu, Doina|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> A [[Border Gateway Protocol]] monitoring site in [[Vancouver, Canada]], reported most of the primary AS (ISPs) dropping a large percentage if not all of route advertisements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bgpmon.net/blog/?p=450|title=BGPMon.net|publisher=bgpmon.net|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Virtually all of Egypt's Internet addresses were unreachable, worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kanalley, Craig|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/27/egypt-internet-goes-down-_n_815156.html |title=Egypt's Internet Shut Down, According to Reports |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> In response, Egyptians used [[smartphone]]s as modems, and even [[land line]]s with [[dial-up modem]]s to make international calls to access the internet, fax machines in universities and embassies, and [[ham radio]] to circumvent the restrictions. Furthermore, the sole remaining functioning ISP, Noor, which had had eight percent of the market share in Egypt, has been reported by the [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor anonymity network]] on 30 January to be the source of a quadrupling of Tor clients from Egypt within twenty-four hours as of 30 January;<ref>Gohring, Nancy; McMillan, Robert (29 January 2011). [http://www.computerworld.com.au/article/374857/without_internet_egyptians_find_new_ways_get_online "Without Internet, Egyptians Find New Ways To Get Online â People Around the World are Offering Dial-Up Modem Numbers and Other Primitive Tools for People in Egypt"]. ''[[IDG]]'' (via ''[[Computerworld]]''). Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref> the use of Tor has sky-rocketed due to the situation in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.torproject.org/blog/recent-events-egypt |title=Recent events in Egypt | The Tor Blog |publisher=Blog.torproject.org |date=30 October 2010 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
Internet access]]<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock">{{cite web| last =Cowie| first =James| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Egypt Leaves the Internet| work =| publisher =[[Renesys]]| date =| url =http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml | doi =| accessdate =28 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w51j0pga |archivedate=28 January 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock">{{cite news | first=Jeremy | last=Kirk | pages= | language =| title=With Wired Internet Locked, Egypt Looks to the Sky | date=28 January 2011 | work=[[IDG News]]/[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] | url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/218064/with_wired_internet_locked_egypt_looks_to_the_sky.html |accessdate=28 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w518Yu9B |archivedate=28 January 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pomed.org/blog/2011/01/egypt-ap-confirms-government-has-disrupted-internet-service.html/ |title=Egypt: AP Confirms Government has Disrupted Internet Service |publisher=pomed.org |date= |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> in an act of unprecedented<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock" /> [[Internet censorship]]. About 3,500 [[Border Gateway Protocol]] (BGP) routes to Egyptian networks were shut down from about 12:10 am to 12:35 am 28 January.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> The shutdown happened within the space of a few tens of minutes, not instantaneously. According to Renesys, [[Telecom Egypt]] started shutting down at 12:12am, [[Vodafone|Raya/Vodafone]] at 12:13am, [[Link Egypt]] at 12:17am, [[Etisalat Misr]] at 12:19am, and [[Internet Egypt]] at 12:25am.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Renesys interpreted the shutdown as people getting phone calls one at a time, telling them to take themselves off the air, rather than an automated system taking all providers down at once.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Facebook confirmed a decrease in traffic from Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-54463420110127|title=Facebook Says Has Seen Drop in Traffic from Egypt|work=[[Reuters]]|author=Oreskovic, Alexei; Chiacu, Doina|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> A [[Border Gateway Protocol]] monitoring site in [[Vancouver, Canada]], reported most of the primary AS (ISPs) dropping a large percentage if not all of route advertisements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bgpmon.net/blog/?p=450|title=BGPMon.net|publisher=bgpmon.net|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Virtually all of Egypt's Internet addresses were unreachable, worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kanalley, Craig|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/27/egypt-internet-goes-down-_n_815156.html |title=Egypt's Internet Shut Down, According to Reports |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> In response, Egyptians used [[smartphone]]s as modems, and even [[land line]]s with [[dial-up modem]]s to make international calls to access the internet, fax machines in universities and embassies, and [[ham radio]] to circumvent the restrictions. Furthermore, the sole remaining functioning ISP, Noor, which had had eight percent of the market share in Egypt, has been reported by the [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor anonymity network]] on 30 January to be the source of a quadrupling of Tor clients from Egypt within twenty-four hours as of 30 January;<ref>Gohring, Nancy; McMillan, Robert (29 January 2011). [http://www.computerworld.com.au/article/374857/without_internet_egyptians_find_new_ways_get_online "Without Internet, Egyptians Find New Ways To Get Online â People Around the World are Offering Dial-Up Modem Numbers and Other Primitive Tools for People in Egypt"]. ''[[IDG]]'' (via ''[[Computerworld]]''). Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref> the use of Tor has sky-rocketed due to the situation in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.torproject.org/blog/recent-events-egypt |title=Recent events in Egypt | The Tor Blog |publisher=Blog.torproject.org |date=30 October 2010 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
â
[[File:Switch off internet in case of political dissent.jpg|thumb|Satirical graphic made{{By whom|date=January 2011}} in reaction to the internet blackout in Egypt]]
 
In response, the U.S. State Department spokesman Philip Crowley said that open communications must be allowed.<ref name="bloomberg1"/> About 24 hours after the blackout began, cellphone and smartphone e-mail access were restored, including Vodafone and Mobinil, though internet access was reportedly still down.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comcast.net/articles/news-general/20110128/ML.Egypt.Protest/|title= Protesters Return to Cairo's Tahrir Square |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]''/[[Comcast]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> Despite the internet blackout, Egyptians abroad have been leading initiatives to spread the news that they get by calling their relatives' landlines.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
In response, the U.S. State Department spokesman Philip Crowley said that open communications must be allowed.<ref name="bloomberg1"/> About 24 hours after the blackout began, cellphone and smartphone e-mail access were restored, including Vodafone and Mobinil, though internet access was reportedly still down.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comcast.net/articles/news-general/20110128/ML.Egypt.Protest/|title= Protesters Return to Cairo's Tahrir Square |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]''/[[Comcast]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> Despite the internet blackout, Egyptians abroad have been leading initiatives to spread the news that they get by calling their relatives' landlines.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
